This only affects the current location where the task is executed.

Marks the current location's dojo (muscle) icon as completed. This updates the location's tooltip icon from 'sign_icon_muscle' to 'sign_icon_muscle_done', indicating that the player has completed the dojo's training. This is typically used when the player finishes combat training or challenges at a dojo location. This only affects the current location where the task is executed.

Creates a treasure map image centered on a specific tile coordinate in the overworld. This command generates a styled screenshot of the overworld area around the specified location, applies visual processing (RGB palette conversion, color adjustments, adds an X mark), frames it, and saves it as the current treasure map. The treasure location coordinates are also stored in global variables. This is used to create treasure hunt quests where players must find specific locations in the game world.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The X coordinate of the treasure location on the overworld map. This is the center point of the area that will be captured in the treasure map image. The value is converted to a TileCoord and stored in the 'treasureTCX' global variable.

required.name: floats[1]
required.description: The Y coordinate of the treasure location on the overworld map. This is the center point of the area that will be captured in the treasure map image. The value is converted to a TileCoord and stored in the 'treasureTCY' global variable.

uses.description: Debug command for testing treasure map generation. This creates a series of treasure map screenshots across the overworld by repeatedly calling itself with advancing coordinates. It loads the overworld zone ('eral') as a special zone, cleans it up by removing certain items and actors, and generates screenshots at regular intervals. By default, it starts at position (100, 100) and advances 20 tiles at a time horizontally, wrapping to the next row when reaching X coordinate 700. This is used for batch-generating map previews or testing the treasure map rendering system.

optional.name: floats[0]
optional.description: The starting X coordinate for the treasure map test screenshot. If not provided, defaults to 100. The command will automatically advance this coordinate for the next iteration.

optional.name: floats[1]
optional.description: The starting Y coordinate for the treasure map test screenshot. If not provided, defaults to 100. The command will automatically advance this coordinate when wrapping to the next row.

uses.description: Adds a buried treasure chest to the zone at the coordinates stored in the global variables 'treasureTCX' and 'treasureTCY'. The treasure chest is a shipwreck location that contains random gold (90-220), a cargo_lost item, two randomized loot items (loot4 and loot3 that are replaced with actual items), and lost documents. After placing the treasure, the global coordinate variables are reset to zero. This task does nothing if the treasure coordinates are not set (treasureTCX is 0). This is used as part of the treasure map quest system.

Replaces a triggered area with content from a zone that's part of a series. This loads a zone whose name is formed by combining the base zone ID with a numeric suffix stored in a global variable, merges it into the current zone at the trigger location, then increments the global variable for the next use. Optionally applies terrain replacers and item removers to the loaded zone before merging. This is useful for progressive events where each trigger reveals the next stage of a zone series.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The base zone ID for the series. The actual zone loaded will be this ID plus a numeric suffix obtained from a global variable with the same name. For example, if this is 'cave' and the global variable 'cave' is 2, it loads zone 'cave2'. After merging, the global variable is incremented.

optional.name: strings[1]
optional.description: Level data string for terrain replacers and item removers. If provided, this is applied to the loaded zone before it's merged into the current zone. This allows customization of the merged content.

uses.description: Reconstructs the player's party from actor IDs or indices stored in global variables. This clears the current party and rebuilds it by looking up each global variable specified in the string list. If a global variable contains a number, it's treated as an index into the existing party actors list. If it contains text, it's treated as an actor ID to find in the current zone. This is useful for restoring a specific party configuration that was saved to global variables.

required.name: strings[0+]
required.description: Global variable names to look up. Each string is the name of a global variable that contains either a numeric party index or an actor ID string. The party is rebuilt in the order these global variables are specified. Multiple strings can be provided to build a party with multiple members.

uses.description: Fully heals all actors in the current zone that belong to a specific faction. This restores HP and MP to maximum for all actors matching the specified faction. The healing does not restore max HP values (only heals up to current max). This is useful for scenario setup or event scripting where you need to ensure a faction starts at full health.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The faction ID of actors to heal. All actors in the current zone with this faction will be fully healed.

uses.description: Removes all temporary party members from the party and related lists. This removes any party actors that cannot be fully controlled, cleaning them from the active party, the missing party list, and the overboard party list. Permanent party members (those with full control) are retained. This is used to clean up temporary companions or guests when they should no longer be with the party.

Removes party actors from the zone who are not in the designated landing party. This checks the landing party list and removes any actors from the zone who aren't included in it. This is used when transitioning to areas where only specific party members should be present, such as landing parties for ship-to-shore missions.

Retrieves all items that can be picked up from a specified zone and adds them to a location in the current zone. This loads the target zone, collects all pickable items from it, and places them at the specified tile coordinate in the current zone. The items are removed from the source zone. This is useful for collecting loot or items from areas without actually visiting them.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The zone ID from which to retrieve items. This zone is loaded temporarily, its pickable items are collected, and then it's unloaded.

optional.name: tileCoords[0]
optional.description: The location to place the retrieved items in the current zone.

uses.description: Attempts to unlock items at the current location. This calls the unlock items method on the current location, which typically checks if requirements are met to unlock special items or rewards at that location. This is part of the location reward and progression system.

Resets the AI state for all fleets in the game. This clears waypoint destinations, pathfinding data, and AI variables for every fleet's flagship, forcing them to recalculate their behavior from scratch. This is useful for resolving stuck fleets or resetting naval AI after major game state changes.

Converts actors marked as escorts into hostile enemies when an enemy fleet is present. This searches for actors with the same faction as the enemy fleet who are marked with combat label 'E' (escort), then changes them to hostile enemies with red exclamation marks. It also clears the 'playerEscort' global variable. This is used for scenarios where escort ships turn against the player.

Opens the journal interface and displays a specific journal entry. The journal opens to the specified entry index with both pages visible, no button cursor, and in a non-interactive display mode. If the journal is already open, it animates forward before showing the new entry. Optionally, all buttons on the journal can be hidden.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The index of the journal entry to display. This is cast to an integer and used to navigate to a specific entry in the player's known journal entries list.

optional.name: bools[0]
optional.description: Whether to hide all buttons on the journal interface. When true, the journal is displayed in a read-only mode with no interactive buttons. When false or not provided, buttons display normally.

uses.description: Opens the journal interface in interactive mode and displays a specific journal entry. Unlike the non-interactive 'openJournal' task, this version allows full player interaction with the journal including navigation and button clicks. If the journal is already open, it animates forward before showing the new entry.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The index of the journal entry to display. This is cast to an integer and used to navigate to a specific entry in the player's known journal entries list.

uses.description: Closes the journal interface if it's currently open. This refreshes the journal state and sets it to not visible, removing it from the screen.

Teaches the player a new journal entry and displays it in the journal. The entry is added to the player's known entries with an optional alert notification. By default, after learning the entry, the journal animates and opens to display the new entry in non-interactive mode. This automatic display can be suppressed with the second bool parameter.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The journal entry ID to learn. This should match a journal entry defined in the game data. The entry is added to the player's known journal entries.

required.name: bools[0]
required.description: Whether to show an alert notification when the journal entry is learned. When true, displays a notification to the player that a new entry was added.

optional.name: bools[1]
optional.description: Whether to suppress the automatic journal opening and display. When true, the journal does not automatically open to show the new entry. When false or not provided, the journal opens and animates to display the newly learned entry.

uses.description: Animates the journal window to a new screen position over a specified duration. The destination position can be specified as absolute coordinates from a tile coordinate, or can be mirrored from the right edge of the screen, or centered on screen. The journal smoothly tweens from its current position to the destination.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The duration of the movement animation in seconds. The journal will smoothly tween from its current position to the destination over this time period.

required.name: bools[0]
required.description: Whether to mirror the X position from the right edge of the screen. When true, the X coordinate is measured from the right edge instead of the left, allowing for right-aligned positioning.

required.name: bools[1]
required.description: Whether to center the journal on screen. When true, ignores the tile coordinate position and centers the journal both horizontally and vertically on the screen. This takes precedence over the mirror setting.

optional.name: tileCoords[0]
optional.description: The destination coordinates for the journal window position. The X and Y values from this tile coordinate are used as the target screen position in pixels. This position can be modified by the bool parameters.

uses.description: Adds a new goal to the player's journal quest tracker. Goals appear in the journal as active objectives. Multiple string arguments are combined with commas to form the complete goal text. The goal is added to the first available goal slot (goal0 through goal19). If the goal already exists, it is not added again. When a new goal is added, the journal opens with a visual flash and sound effect to highlight the new entry.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The first part of the goal text. This is the base description or main objective of the goal.

optional.name: strings[1+]
optional.description: Additional parts of the goal text. Each additional string is appended to the goal text separated by commas. Empty strings are skipped. This allows building complex, multi-part goal descriptions from separate components.

uses.description: Marks a journal goal as completed by drawing a line through it in the quest tracker. The goal text must exactly match an existing active goal (including any comma-separated components). When completed, the journal opens with a visual flash and completion sound effect. By default, completing a goal awards 50 XP to all crew members and adds a brief interaction delay. The XP reward and delay can be suppressed with a bool parameter.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The first part of the goal text to complete. This must match the first part of an existing active goal.

optional.name: strings[1+]
optional.description: Additional parts of the goal text to complete. Each string is appended with commas to form the complete goal identifier. The assembled text must exactly match an existing goal to be marked complete.

optional.name: bools[0]
optional.description: Whether to suppress the XP reward and interaction delay. When true, the goal is marked complete without awarding XP or adding delay. When false or not provided, awards 50 XP to all crew and adds a 0.6 second interaction delay.

uses.description: Sets the sprite offset multipliers for a specific terrain type. These multipliers affect how the terrain sprite is positioned relative to its tile, allowing for visual adjustments and variations in terrain rendering. This is a debug/development tool for tuning terrain appearance.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The terrain type ID to modify. This identifies which terrain type's sprite offset multipliers should be changed.

optional.name: tileCoords[0]
optional.description: The sprite offset multiplier values. The X coordinate sets the horizontal sprite offset multiplier, and the Y coordinate sets the vertical sprite offset multiplier for the terrain type.

uses.description: Sets the sprite offset modulo values for a specific terrain type. These modulo values create variation in sprite positioning by applying a modulo operation to tile coordinates, allowing terrain sprites to have controlled positional variation across tiles. This is a debug/development tool for creating visual variety in terrain.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The terrain type ID to modify. This identifies which terrain type's sprite offset modulo values should be changed.

optional.name: tileCoords[0]
optional.description: The sprite offset modulo values. The X coordinate sets the horizontal sprite offset modulo, and the Y coordinate sets the vertical sprite offset modulo for the terrain type.

uses.description: Sets the sprite offset modulo values for all terrain types whose IDs start with a specific prefix. This allows bulk modification of multiple related terrain types at once. The modulo values create variation in sprite positioning across tiles, useful for creating visual variety in terrain rendering. This is a debug/development tool for batch-updating terrain appearance.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The terrain type ID prefix. All terrain types whose IDs start with this string will have their sprite offset modulo values updated. For example, 'grass' would affect 'grass1', 'grass2', 'grassland', etc.

optional.name: tileCoords[0]
optional.description: The sprite offset modulo values to apply. The X coordinate sets the horizontal sprite offset modulo, and the Y coordinate sets the vertical sprite offset modulo for all matching terrain types.

uses.description: Reveals fog of war around the task's assigned actor at their current position. This calls the fog discovery function multiple times (4 times) to ensure a thorough reveal of the surrounding area. This is typically used when entering a new area or when an event should reveal the nearby terrain.

Directly sets the fog of war state (known/unknown) for a square area of tiles. This can reveal or hide areas in the fog of war without requiring actor movement or line of sight. The area is centered on the tile coordinate from the task and extends outward by the specified radius. Optionally, this can modify fog of war for a different zone than the current one.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The radius of the square area to modify. The fog state is set for all tiles in a square from (center - radius) to (center + radius). This is cast to an integer.

required.name: bools[0]
required.description: The fog state to set. When true, tiles are marked as known (revealed). When false, tiles are marked as unknown (hidden/fogged).

optional.name: strings[0]
optional.description: The zone ID for which to modify fog of war. If provided and not empty, modifies fog for that zone instead of the current zone. This allows modifying fog in zones the player isn't currently in. If empty or not provided, uses the current zone.

optional.name: tileCoords[0]
optional.description: The center point of the fog modification area. The fog of war state will be changed for tiles around this coordinate.

uses.description: Resets the reaction timers for all tiles in the current zone. Tiles track when they were last reacted with (for elemental reactions, effects, etc.) to prevent rapid repeated reactions. This task clears all those timers, allowing tiles to react immediately again. This is useful for resetting zone state or enabling repeated environmental effects.

Changes which party member is the currently controlled player character. This switches control to the specified actor without any additional side effects like reordering the party, playing effects, or bringing other actors forward. The change is immediate and minimal.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The actor ID of the party member to make the new player-controlled character. This actor must be in the current party.

uses.description: Reads a property or field value from an actor and stores it in a global variable as a string. This allows extracting actor data (position, stats, state, etc.) and saving it for later use in scripts or conditions. The property is accessed via reflection, so any public field or property of the Actor class can be retrieved.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The name of the global variable to set. The actor's property value will be stored in this global variable as a string.

required.name: strings[1]
required.description: The actor ID whose property should be read. This identifies which actor in the current zone to get data from.

required.name: strings[2]
required.description: The property or field name to read from the actor. This should be the name of a public property or field on the Actor class (e.g., 'HP', 'positionTC', 'faction', etc.). The value is retrieved via reflection.

uses.description: Debug command that automatically travels through multiple zones for testing purposes. This generates a list of zone files that don't match known level data prefixes (excluding special zones like procedural zones starting with 'sp', 'grove', 'den', 'bz'), then creates a series of timed travel tasks to visit them sequentially. Each zone visit shows a counter on screen. After queuing all travel tasks, the game switches to travel mode. This is useful for batch-testing zones or creating automated zone tours.

optional.name: floats[0]
optional.description: The maximum number of zones to visit per iteration. If not provided, all discovered zones are visited. This can be used to limit the test run to a specific number of zones.

optional.name: floats[1]
optional.description: The number of times to iterate through the zone list. Each iteration visits up to the maximum number of zones. If not provided, defaults to 1 iteration. This is cast to an integer.

uses.description: Immediately stops the current AI-controlled actor's turn in combat and disables further AI processing. This ends the current AI actor's turn and prevents the AI system from processing any more actions until re-enabled. This is useful for interrupting AI behavior during combat, such as when transitioning to a cutscene or special event. This only has an effect if combat mode is active and an uncontrollable (AI) actor is currently acting.

Re-enables AI processing in combat. This allows the AI system to continue processing turns for AI-controlled actors. This is typically used after stopCombatAIActing or another event that disabled AI processing, to resume normal combat behavior.

Moves actors away from a specific location to nearby positions outside a defined radius. This finds all actors within a radius of a center point, then relocates them to occupiable tiles just outside that radius. Optionally filters by faction and can trigger pain animations. This is useful for clearing an area of actors or creating space around a specific location. If party actors are relocated, their movement paths are cleared.

optional.name: floats[0]
optional.description: The radius in tiles around the center point. Actors within this radius are relocated to positions at least this far from the center. If not provided, defaults to 1 tile. The value is cast to an integer.

optional.name: strings[0]
optional.description: The faction to filter by. If provided, only actors of this faction are relocated. If empty or not provided, all actors within the radius are relocated regardless of faction.

optional.name: bools[0]
optional.description: Whether to play a pain animation when relocating actors. When true, each relocated actor plays their pain animation as they are moved, providing visual feedback of the displacement.

optional.name: tileCoords[0]
optional.description: The center point from which actors should be relocated. Actors within the specified radius of this coordinate will be moved to positions outside the radius.

uses.description: Relocates actors to specific travel points in the zone. This finds all actors within a radius of a center coordinate (optionally filtered by faction), then distributes them to available travel point items in the zone. The actors are placed on travel points matching a specific set number. This is useful for teleporting groups of actors to designated spawn points or positioning areas.

required.name: bools[0]
required.description: First boolean parameter passed to the actor placement function, controlling some aspect of how actors are positioned on travel points.

required.name: bools[1]
required.description: Second boolean parameter passed to the actor placement function, controlling another aspect of how actors are positioned on travel points.

optional.name: floats[0]
optional.description: The radius in tiles to search for actors around the center point. If not provided, defaults to 1 tile. The value is cast to an integer.

optional.name: strings[0]
optional.description: The faction to filter by. If provided, only actors of this faction are relocated. If empty or not provided, all actors within the radius are candidates for relocation.

optional.name: strings[1]
optional.description: The travel point set number. Actors are placed on travel point items matching this set number. If not provided, defaults to 0. This is parsed as an integer.

optional.name: tileCoords[0]
optional.description: The center point for finding actors to relocate. All actors within the specified radius of this coordinate are candidates for relocation.

uses.description: Extracts a specific crew member from a boarded enemy ship and places them in the zone. This searches the crew of the currently boarded target ship for an actor matching a specific actor type ID, then places that actor at a designated travel point and adds them to the active zone. This is used during boarding scenarios to bring specific enemy crew members into combat or interaction.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The actor type ID of the crew member to extract from the boarded ship. The first crew member matching this type ID will be placed in the zone at the specified travel point.

uses.description: Converts the current location into the player's home port with all associated facilities and services. This comprehensive setup adds port functionality, shipwright services (selling cog, caravel, and pinnace boats), cafe service with basic food, hiring services for humans and scurio, a home icon, quest generation, location stash with starting supplies (lifeshards, revive dust, splints, shovel, XP gems, random action tablets), and an unlockable ability crest. If a player faction is set, the port becomes everloyal to that faction. This is typically used when the player establishes their base of operations.

Adds a tooltip icon to the current location's icon list. These icons appear on the location to indicate available services or features (such as training, shops, quests, etc.). The icon is appended to the end of the existing icon list.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The icon ID to add to the location. This should be a valid tooltip icon identifier (e.g., 'sign_icon_book' for training, 'sign_icon_muscle' for combat training, etc.).

uses.description: Converts a party member into an NPC vendor at a specific location. This removes the actor from the party (without adding them to barracks), makes them non-swappable, sets their dialog node, marks them as a reserved actor, and places them at a designated travel point. If another actor with the same dialog role already exists at that location, they swap places (the old vendor returns to the party and the new vendor takes their position). This is used for setting up party members as shopkeepers, quest givers, or other service NPCs.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The index of the party actor to convert into a vendor. This is an index into the current party actors list, cast to an integer. If the party doesn't have enough members (index out of range), the task does nothing.

required.name: floats[1]
required.description: The travel point number where the vendor should be positioned. The actor is placed at this travel point location (with set number 0). Cast to an integer.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The dialog node ID for the vendor. This determines what dialog tree the vendor uses when interacted with (e.g., 'questgiver' for quest givers, shop dialog IDs for merchants, etc.).

uses.description: Converts an NPC vendor back into a party member. This finds an actor at a specified travel point who has a specific dialog role, clears their dialog assignment, and adds them back to the party. The actor is then moved to a position near the player. This is the reverse of setPartyActorAsVendor, used to reclaim party members who were assigned as vendors.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The travel point number where the vendor is located. The task looks for an actor at this travel point (with set number 0) to convert back into a party member. Cast to an integer.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The dialog node ID that identifies the vendor to remove. Only actors with this exact dialog node ID will be converted back to party members. This ensures the correct vendor is targeted.

uses.description: Prompts the player to name a port by opening a text input dialog. This switches to travel mode and displays a confirmation dialog asking 'What will you name the port?' with text input enabled. The dialog connects to the 'renamePort' confirmation handler and cannot be closed by the player until they provide a name. This is used when establishing a new port or allowing the player to customize their home port's name.

Dynamically generates dialog options for a cafe food menu based on discovered food items. This clears the specified dialog node's options and rebuilds them with available food choices. It always includes basic food, then adds special regional foods discovered at other locations (with specific wealth requirements). Each option shows the food item with its cost, description, and effects. Selecting an option changes the cafe's food offering. This creates a dynamic menu system where discovering new locations unlocks new food options at the player's port cafe.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The dialog node ID whose options should be populated with cafe food choices. This dialog node will have its options cleared and replaced with dynamically generated food menu items.

uses.description: Changes the cafe food offering at the current location. This can either set the cafe food to a specific item type ID, or copy the cafe food and hiring services from another location. When given a location ID, it copies both the cafe food type and the auto-spawn hiring options from that location to the current location. When given an item type ID (if no matching location exists), it simply sets the cafe food to that item.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The location ID or item type ID to use. If this matches a location ID, the current location's cafe food and hiring services are copied from that location. If no location matches, this is treated as an item type ID and the cafe food is set to that item directly.

uses.description: Awards XP to all actors in the zone with a specific dialog node ID based on a formula calculation. The XP amount is calculated from a formula and capped so the recipient doesn't exceed the main player's total XP earned. This is useful for keeping NPC levels synchronized with the player. The XP is awarded silently without visual feedback, ignoring tired penalties and party size modifiers.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The dialog node ID to match. All actors in the current zone with this dialog node ID will receive XP. This is typically used to identify specific NPCs like trainers, vendors, or quest givers.

required.name: strings[1]
required.description: The formula string to calculate the XP amount. This formula is evaluated to determine how much XP to award. The result is capped to ensure the recipient doesn't exceed the main player's total XP, and negative values are floored at 0.

uses.description: Converts all player-owned ports in the overworld to a specific faction. This searches for all locations on the overworld map ('eral') that are tagged as player ports ('sport') and sets them to be everloyal to the specified faction. This is used when the player aligns with or establishes a faction, making all their ports loyal to that faction.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The faction ID to convert player ports to. All player ports will be set as everloyal to this faction, affecting their diplomatic relationships and behavior.

uses.description: Adds an unlockable item to the current location's unlock system. Unlockable items become available for purchase or access when certain conditions (typically wealth/prosperity level) are met. After adding the unlockable, this task attempts to unlock any items whose conditions are now satisfied. This is used to expand a location's available goods and services as it develops.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The item type ID of the item to add as an unlockable. This is what will become available at the location when conditions are met.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The quantity or amount of the unlockable item. This determines how many of the item are available when unlocked.

required.name: strings[1]
required.description: The formula string that defines the unlock condition. This formula is evaluated to determine when the item should become available (e.g., 'm:locWealth(90)' requires location wealth of 90 or higher).

uses.description: Executes a task whose name is stored in a global variable. This retrieves a global variable's string value and, if it's not '0', treats that value as a task name and executes it. This allows dynamic task execution where the specific task to run is determined by game state stored in global variables. This is useful for branching scenarios where different tasks should execute based on player choices or game conditions.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The name of the global variable to read. The value of this global variable (if not '0') is used as the task name to execute. The task name should be a valid task type that can be constructed and executed.

uses.description: Debug command that instantly makes all ports in the world wealthy and loyal to the player's faction. This sets every port location in the overworld to maximum wealth (100) and, if a player faction is defined, makes them all everloyal to that faction. This is a cheat command for testing or achieving instant world domination.

Debug command that forces garbage collection to free memory. This clears extra zones from memory and runs the .NET garbage collector twice with finalization between runs. This is useful for freeing up memory during development or when experiencing memory issues. The aggressive collection pattern ensures thorough cleanup of managed resources.

Debug command that clears all debug display queues and on-screen debug strings. This removes all debug visualizations, indefinite debug drawings, and darkness-ignoring draw elements from the screen. This is useful for cleaning up debug displays during development.

Debug command that displays a labeled string on screen. This shows a debug message with a category label and content, similar to debugMessage but with a different implementation. The message persists on screen for debugging purposes. If either parameter is missing or the first string is empty, the command does nothing.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The category label for the debug message. This must not be empty for the message to display. The label identifies what the debug information represents.

required.name: strings[1]
required.description: The content of the debug message to display on screen. This is the actual debug information shown alongside the category label.

uses.description: Loads and transitions to a new zone with specific camera positioning. This moves the game to a different zone, placing the camera at specified coordinates with defined width and height parameters. This is a zone transition command that provides control over the initial camera view in the new zone.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The zone ID to load and transition to. This should be a valid zone identifier from the game's zone data.

required.name: floats[0]
required.description: The camera width parameter for the new zone. This affects the horizontal extent of the camera view when entering the zone.

required.name: floats[1]
required.description: The camera height parameter for the new zone. This affects the vertical extent of the camera view when entering the zone.

uses.description: Sets the game window's maximized state. This either maximizes the window to fill the screen or restores it to windowed mode, depending on the boolean parameter. This provides control over the window display mode.

required.name: bools[0]
required.description: Whether to maximize the window. When true, the window is maximized to full screen. When false, the window is restored to its previous windowed size.

uses.description: Conditionally maximizes the window and hides UI elements if the boolean parameter is true. When activated, this maximizes the window, hides the main menu background, and hides the UI manager. This is useful for entering a clean full-screen mode for specific scenarios like cutscenes or presentations.

required.name: bools[0]
required.description: Whether to maximize and clean the display. When true, maximizes the window and hides the main menu background and UI manager. When false, does nothing.

uses.description: Triggers a screen resolution change using the game's resolution change system. This calls the resolution change method which applies any pending resolution changes that were previously queued. This is typically used after setting a target resolution with other commands.

Uploads a new mod to the Steam Workshop. This validates the specified mod folder, then initiates the Steam Workshop upload process by creating a new Workshop item. A confirmation dialog appears during the upload process, and user interaction is blocked until the upload completes. This is used to publish new mods to Steam Workshop for the first time.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The mod folder name to upload. This folder must exist in the mod data directory and pass validation checks. The folder should contain the mod content and a preview image with the same name as the folder.

uses.description: Sets the current mod ID for subsequent mod operations. This parses a Steam Workshop published file ID from a string and stores it for use with other mod-related tasks like editing or viewing. If the string cannot be parsed as a valid ID, sets the mod ID to 0. This is used to target a specific Workshop item for editing or management.

required.name: strings[0]
required.description: The Steam Workshop published file ID as a string. This should be the numeric ID of a Workshop item. If this cannot be parsed as a valid unsigned long integer, the mod ID is set to 0.

uses.description: Updates an existing mod on the Steam Workshop. This validates the mod folder, then initiates a Steam Workshop update for the previously set mod ID (from getmod task). The update includes the mod content and preview image. A confirmation dialog appears during upload and user interaction is blocked until complete. This is used to publish updates to existing Workshop mods.

uses.description: Updates only the tags for an existing Steam Workshop mod. This concatenates all provided strings, parses them as tags, and updates the tags for the previously set mod ID (from getmod task) without changing the mod content. A confirmation dialog appears during the upload process. This is useful for updating mod categorization and discoverability without re-uploading content.
